cluster_relations.rel_desc: Gestures are described as an aspect or component of body language.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a component, aspect, or example of the object, which represents a larger whole, system, or category.
remarks: Direction set from gestures to body language as part-to-whole.
Direction set from gestures to body language as part-to-whole.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Facial expressions are implicitly framed as one aspect of body language, with gestures being 'another' aspect.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a component, aspect, or example of the object, which represents a larger whole, system, or category.
remarks: Relation partly inferred from discourse structure; semantics match standard definition of body language.
Relation partly inferred from discourse structure; semantics match standard definition of body language.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Nonverbal cues constitute a substantial portion of overall communication.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a contributing component, modality, or channel within the larger process or system represented by the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a part, aspect, or modality of the larger whole, system, or process represented by the object.
args.justification: All three relations represent a consistent part–whole/component relation and already share the same canonical_rel_name. However, they currently have slightly different and partly confusing canonical_rel_desc texts (including wording like 'example of' and 'category' that can blur part-of vs instance-of semantics). Unifying them under a single clear description focused on part/aspect/modality of a larger whole improves schema consistency without changing their more specific rel_cls distinctions.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a part, aspect, or modality of the larger whole, system, or process represented by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations represent a consistent part–whole/component relation and already share the same canonical_rel_name. However, they currently have slightly different and partly confusing canonical_rel_desc texts (including wording like 'example of' and 'category' that can blur part-of vs instance-of semantics). Unifying them under a single clear description focused on part/aspect/modality of a larger whole improves schema consistency without changing their more specific rel_cls distinctions.
